original_title: Sri Lanka to expand domestic drug production by 35-pct
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is planning to expand domestic pharmaceutical productions 35 percent, Keheliya Rambuwelle, Minister of Health said.

Currently around 190 drugs out of the 800 in the Central Medical Centre are in shortage, while Medical Centres across the island are short of 90 drugs, Rambukwelle said, addressing a tri-monthly summit held on 30 June.

“Medicines have protections and standards to be met in order to be imported. To see those processes through, it takes at least 9 months, ” Rambukwelle said, addressing a  tri-monthly summit held on 30 June.

According to a statement released by the President’s Media Division on 3 July, the government is in the process of planning to produce 17 additional drugs to the 19 that are already being produced locally, by the next quarter of the year.
“Over the next two years, we aim to increase the production of domestically made medicines by 30 percent to 35 percent,” the statement said.
In January 2023, investment agreements to construct 12 factories to produce essential pharmaceutical products were handed over to 12 local investors.

The ‘Suvasiripura’ pharma zone dedicated to the production of medicinal drugs in Oyamaduwa, Anuradhapura is expected to produce 40 percent of drugs required annually in Sri Lanka and increase it to 60 percent over the next couple of years. (Colombo/July06/2023)
